Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Control of Quantum Defects in Low-Dimensional Carbon Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor YuHuang Wang of the University of Maryland to investigate the effect of chemical defects on the physical properties of linear and two dimensional carbon materials. As with islands in the sea, these defects serve as focusing points of activity on an otherwise plain surface. These points are where interesting new chemistry and physics can occur. Successful completion of the proposed study may open an entirely new approach to engineering materials that could translate into new entries into optical probes and selective chemical sensors. The proposed work is also projected to engage undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, directly in the research program through graduate-undergraduate mentorship.

The proposed defects are being synthetically created in Prof. Wang's laboratory by covalently attaching a controlled number of functional groups to semiconducting carbon nanotube model systems. The beauty of this type of defect is its better-defined structure, excellent chemical tunability, and more importantly, previously unexpected fluorescent properties. An exciton, or electron-hole pair, can light up at the quantum defect site, making it possible to experimentally probe defects using conventional spectroscopic techniques. These chemically tailored, fluorescent quantum defects will be explored as a new tool to engineer nanomaterials, potentially to break the dark exciton limit of nanotube photoluminescence, and to probe chemical events that could be otherwise difficult to capture.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The science goal of this project is to elucidate the fundamental impact of chemical defects on the electronic properties of low-dimensional carbon materials. The education activities include involving undergraduate students in cutting edge research. 

Intellectual Merit. The key findings from this project have been summarized and reported in 14 refereed articles in journals of very high impact, including the Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters, ACS Nano, the Journal of the American Chemical Society, Angewandte Chemie International Edition, and four others. Based on work funded by this award one U.S. patent has been granted.

A major advance is the synthesis of molecularly tunable fluorescent quantum defects. By covalently bonding surface functional groups that are themselves non-emitting, we show that the same carbon nanotube crystal can be chemically converted to create more than 30 distinct fluorescent nanostructures with unique near-infrared photoluminescence that is molecularly specific, systematically tunable, and significantly brighter than the parent semiconductor. We further find that exciton localization at the defects has a dramatic effect on their photoluminescence lifetimes. Collaborating with Los Alamos National Laboratory through a user project that complements our NSF award, we measure photoluminescence decay dynamics of sp3 defect states introduced by aryl functionalization of the carbon nanotube surface. By probing the chirality dependence of the decay times, we find a strong emission-energy dependence that indicates the nonradiative decay mechanism for the defect states is primarily by multi-phonon decay. Significantly, the observations also provide a strong experimental evidence that E11 dark excitons are also trapped at defect sites.  This is an important step in understanding how dark excitons may be converted to bright emitting trap states as a route to boosting SWCNT photoluminescence quantum yields.

Broader Impacts. This project has helped open a new frontier of research on defects. The key findings from this project have been disseminated by students in 15 presentations/posters at national and international conferences including one invited Gordon Research Seminar. Additionally, the PI has presented the work in a number of invited talks at national and international conferences. Through our synthetic creation and fundamental understanding of molecularly tunable fluorescent quantum defects in low-dimensional carbon materials, our work is generating a growing impact in the areas of materials chemistry and photophysics, and the various photonic applications of sp3 quantum defects. It may also lead to new insights in areas such as photovoltaics where exciton diffusion, trapping and quenching are fundamentally important to energy harvesting and conversion.

On the training side, this project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas, nanochemistry in particular. Three undergraduate researchers were recruited to participate in this project and subsequently entered medical or graduate schools. The grant also helps support three graduate students who have successfully defended their dissertations and taken industrial jobs or accepted a postdoctoral position planning for an academic career. Over the award duration, the trainees who have been fully or partially supported by this grant have been recognized by a number of awards, including the ACS Analytical Chemistry Award, the Gary & Sue Christian Graduate Award, the Millard & Lee Alexander Fellowship, the Fulbright Scholarship, the Analytical Chemistry Award, and the Student Travel Award for the ACS National Meeting.
